text:
How the city sits solitary,
    that was full of people!
She has become as a widow,
    who was great among the nations!
She who was a princess among the provinces
    has become a slave!
speaker: Narrator

text:
She weeps bitterly in the night.
    Her tears are on her cheeks.
Among all her lovers
    she has no one to comfort her.
All her friends have dealt treacherously with her.
    They have become her enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Judah has gone into captivity because of affliction
    and because of great servitude.
She dwells among the nations.
    She finds no rest.
    All her persecutors overtook her in her distress.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The roads to Zion mourn,
    because no one comes to the solemn assembly.
All her gates are desolate.
    Her priests sigh.
Her virgins are afflicted,
    and she herself is in bitterness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Her adversaries have become the head.
    Her enemies prosper;
for Yahweh has afflicted her for the multitude of her transgressions.
    Her young children have gone into captivity before the adversary.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All majesty has departed from the daughter of Zion.
    Her princes have become like deer that find no pasture.
    They have gone without strength before the pursuer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jerusalem remembers in the days of her affliction and of her miseries
    all her pleasant things that were from the days of old;
when her people fell into the hand of the adversary,
    and no one helped her.
The adversaries saw her.
    They mocked at her desolations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jerusalem has grievously sinned.
    Therefore she has become unclean.
All who honored her despise her,
    because they have seen her nakedness.
    Yes, she sighs and turns backward.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Her filthiness was in her skirts.
    She didn’t remember her latter end.
Therefore she has come down astoundingly.
    She has no comforter.
“See, Yahweh, my affliction;
    for the enemy has magnified himself.”
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
All her people sigh.
    They seek bread.
    They have given their pleasant things for food to refresh their soul.
“Look, Yahweh, and see,
    for I have become despised.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Is it nothing to you, all you who pass by?
    Look, and see if there is any sorrow like my sorrow,
    which is brought on me,
    with which Yahweh has afflicted me in the day of his fierce anger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“From on high has he sent fire into my bones,
    and it prevails against them.
He has spread a net for my feet.
    He has turned me back.
    He has made me desolate and I faint all day long.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The yoke of my transgressions is bound by his hand.
    They are knit together.
    They have come up on my neck.
    He made my strength fail.
The Lord has delivered me into their hands,
    against whom I am not able to stand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The Lord has set at nothing all my mighty men within me.
    He has called a solemn assembly against me to crush my young men.
    The Lord has trodden the virgin daughter of Judah as in a wine press.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“For these things I weep.
    My eye, my eye runs down with water,
    because the comforter who should refresh my soul is far from me.
My children are desolate,
    because the enemy has prevailed.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Zion spreads out her hands.
    There is no one to comfort her.
Yahweh has commanded concerning Jacob,
    that those who are around him should be his adversaries.
    Jerusalem is among them as an unclean thing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Yahweh is righteous,
    for I have rebelled against his commandment.
Please hear all you peoples,
    and see my sorrow.
    My virgins and my young men have gone into captivity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I called for my lovers,
    but they deceived me.
My priests and my elders gave up the spirit in the city,
    while they sought food for themselves to refresh their souls.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Look, Yahweh; for I am in distress.
    My heart is troubled.
My heart turns over within me,
    for I have grievously rebelled.
Abroad, the sword bereaves.
    At home, it is like death.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“They have heard that I sigh.
    There is no one to comfort me.
All my enemies have heard of my trouble.
    They are glad that you have done it.
You will bring the day that you have proclaimed,
    and they will be like me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Let all their wickedness come before you.
    Do to them as you have done to me for all my transgressions.
For my sighs are many,
    and my heart is faint.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How has the Lord covered the daughter of Zion with a cloud in his anger!
    He has cast the beauty of Israel down from heaven to the earth,
    and hasn’t remembered his footstool in the day of his anger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord has swallowed up all the dwellings of Jacob
    without pity.
He has thrown down in his wrath the strongholds of the daughter of Judah.
    He has brought them down to the ground.
    He has profaned the kingdom and its princes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has cut off all the horn of Israel in fierce anger.
    He has drawn back his right hand from before the enemy.
He has burned up Jacob like a flaming fire,
    which devours all around.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has bent his bow like an enemy.
    He has stood with his right hand as an adversary.
He has killed all that were pleasant to the eye.
    In the tent of the daughter of Zion, he has poured out his wrath like fire.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord has become as an enemy.
    He has swallowed up Israel.
He has swallowed up all her palaces.
    He has destroyed his strongholds.
    He has multiplied mourning and lamentation in the daughter of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has violently taken away his tabernacle,
    as if it were a garden.
He has destroyed his place of assembly.
    Yahweh has caused solemn assembly and Sabbath to be forgotten in Zion.
    In the indignation of his anger, he has despised the king and the priest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord has cast off his altar.
    He has abhorred his sanctuary.
He has given the walls of her palaces into the hand of the enemy.
    They have made a noise in Yahweh’s house,
    as in the day of a solemn assembly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yahweh has purposed to destroy the wall of the daughter of Zion.
    He has stretched out the line.
    He has not withdrawn his hand from destroying;
He has made the rampart and wall lament.
    They languish together.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Her gates have sunk into the ground.
    He has destroyed and broken her bars.
Her king and her princes are among the nations where the law is not.
    Yes, her prophets find no vision from Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The elders of the daughter of Zion sit on the ground.
    They keep silence.
They have cast up dust on their heads.
    They have clothed themselves with sackcloth.
    The virgins of Jerusalem hang down their heads to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My eyes fail with tears.
    My heart is troubled.
My bile is poured on the earth,
    because of the destruction of the daughter of my people,
    because the young children and the infants swoon in the streets of the city.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They ask their mothers,
    “Where is grain and wine?”
    when they swoon as the wounded in the streets of the city,
    when their soul is poured out into their mothers’ bosom.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What shall I testify to you?
    What shall I liken to you, daughter of Jerusalem?
What shall I compare to you,
    that I may comfort you, virgin daughter of Zion?
For your breach is as big as the sea.
    Who can heal you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your prophets have seen false and foolish visions for you.
    They have not uncovered your iniquity,
    to reverse your captivity,
    but have seen for you false revelations and causes of banishment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All that pass by clap their hands at you.
    They hiss and wag their head at the daughter of Jerusalem, saying,
“Is this the city that men called ‘The perfection of beauty,
    the joy of the whole earth’?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
All your enemies have opened their mouth wide against you.
    They hiss and gnash their teeth.
    They say, “We have swallowed her up.
Certainly this is the day that we looked for.
    We have found it.
    We have seen it.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yahweh has done that which he planned.
    He has fulfilled his word that he commanded in the days of old.
He has thrown down,
    and has not pitied.
He has caused the enemy to rejoice over you.
    He has exalted the horn of your adversaries.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their heart cried to the Lord.
    O wall of the daughter of Zion,
    let tears run down like a river day and night.
Give yourself no relief.
    Don’t let your eyes rest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Arise, cry out in the night,
    at the beginning of the watches!
Pour out your heart like water before the face of the Lord.
    Lift up your hands toward him for the life of your young children,
    who faint for hunger at the head of every street.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Look, Yahweh, and see to whom you have done thus!
    Should the women eat their offspring,
    the children that they held and bounced on their knees?
    Should the priest and the prophet be killed in the sanctuary of the Lord?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The youth and the old man lie on the ground in the streets.
    My virgins and my young men have fallen by the sword.
You have killed them in the day of your anger.
    You have slaughtered, and not pitied.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“You have called, as in the day of a solemn assembly, my terrors on every side.
    There was no one that escaped or remained in the day of Yahweh’s anger.
    My enemy has consumed those whom I have cared for and brought up.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am the man who has seen affliction
    by the rod of his wrath.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has led me and caused me to walk in darkness,
    and not in light.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Surely he turns his hand against me
    again and again all day long.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has made my flesh and my skin old.
    He has broken my bones.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has built against me,
    and surrounded me with bitterness and hardship.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has made me dwell in dark places,
    as those who have been long dead.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has walled me about, so that I can’t go out.
    He has made my chain heavy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yes, when I cry, and call for help,
    he shuts out my prayer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has walled up my ways with cut stone.
    He has made my paths crooked.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He is to me as a bear lying in wait,
    as a lion in hiding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has turned away my path,
    and pulled me in pieces.
    He has made me desolate.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has bent his bow,
    and set me as a mark for the arrow.
speaker: Narrator

text: He has caused the shafts of his quiver to enter into my kidneys.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have become a derision to all my people,
    and their song all day long.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has filled me with bitterness.
    He has stuffed me with wormwood.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has also broken my teeth with gravel.
    He has covered me with ashes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have removed my soul far away from peace.
    I forgot prosperity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I said, “My strength has perished,
    along with my expectation from Yahweh.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Remember my affliction and my misery,
    the wormwood and the bitterness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My soul still remembers them,
    and is bowed down within me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This I recall to my mind;
    therefore I have hope.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is because of Yahweh’s loving kindnesses that we are not consumed,
    because his mercies don’t fail.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are new every morning.
    Great is your faithfulness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Yahweh is my portion,” says my soul.
    “Therefore I will hope in him.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yahweh is good to those who wait for him,
    to the soul who seeks him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is good that a man should hope
    and quietly wait for the salvation of Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is good for a man that he bear the yoke in his youth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let him sit alone and keep silence,
    because he has laid it on him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let him put his mouth in the dust,
    if it is so that there may be hope.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let him give his cheek to him who strikes him.
    Let him be filled full of reproach.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord will not cast off forever.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For though he causes grief,
    yet he will have compassion according to the multitude of his loving kindnesses.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For he does not afflict willingly,
    nor grieve the children of men.
speaker: Narrator

text: To crush under foot all the prisoners of the earth,
speaker: Narrator

text: to turn away the right of a man before the face of the Most High,
speaker: Narrator

text: to subvert a man in his cause, the Lord doesn’t approve.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who is he who says, and it comes to pass,
    when the Lord doesn’t command it?
speaker: Narrator

text: Doesn’t evil and good come out of the mouth of the Most High?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why should a living man complain,
    a man for the punishment of his sins?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let us search and try our ways,
    and turn again to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let’s lift up our heart with our hands to God in the heavens.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“We have transgressed and have rebelled.
    You have not pardoned.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“You have covered us with anger and pursued us.
    You have killed.
    You have not pitied.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have covered yourself with a cloud,
    so that no prayer can pass through.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have made us an off-scouring and refuse
    in the middle of the peoples.
speaker: Narrator

text: “All our enemies have opened their mouth wide against us.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Terror and the pit have come on us,
    devastation and destruction.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
My eye runs down with streams of water,
    for the destruction of the daughter of my people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My eye pours down
    and doesn’t cease,
    without any intermission,
speaker: Narrator

text:
until Yahweh looks down,
    and sees from heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My eye affects my soul,
    because of all the daughters of my city.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They have chased me relentlessly like a bird,
    those who are my enemies without cause.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They have cut off my life in the dungeon,
    and have cast a stone on me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Waters flowed over my head.
    I said, “I am cut off.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
I called on your name, Yahweh,
    out of the lowest dungeon.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You heard my voice:
    “Don’t hide your ear from my sighing,
    and my cry.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
You came near in the day that I called on you.
    You said, “Don’t be afraid.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Lord, you have pleaded the causes of my soul.
    You have redeemed my life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yahweh, you have seen my wrong.
    Judge my cause.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have seen all their vengeance
    and all their plans against me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have heard their reproach, Yahweh,
    and all their plans against me,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the lips of those that rose up against me,
    and their plots against me all day long.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You see their sitting down and their rising up.
    I am their song.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will pay them back, Yahweh,
    according to the work of their hands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will give them hardness of heart,
    your curse to them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will pursue them in anger,
    and destroy them from under the heavens of Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How the gold has become dim!
    The most pure gold has changed!
The stones of the sanctuary are poured out
    at the head of every street.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The precious sons of Zion,
    comparable to fine gold,
how they are esteemed as earthen pitchers,
    the work of the hands of the potter!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even the jackals offer their breast.
    They nurse their young ones.
But the daughter of my people has become cruel,
    like the ostriches in the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The tongue of the nursing child clings to the roof of his mouth for thirst.
    The young children ask for bread,
    and no one breaks it for them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who ate delicacies are desolate in the streets.
    Those who were brought up in purple embrace dunghills.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the iniquity of the daughter of my people is greater than the sin of Sodom,
    which was overthrown as in a moment.
    No hands were laid on her.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Her nobles were purer than snow.
    They were whiter than milk.
They were more ruddy in body than rubies.
    Their polishing was like sapphire.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their appearance is blacker than a coal.
    They are not known in the streets.
Their skin clings to their bones.
    It is withered.
    It has become like wood.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
The hands of the pitiful women have boiled their own children.
    They were their food in the destruction of the daughter of my people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yahweh has accomplished his wrath.
    He has poured out his fierce anger.
He has kindled a fire in Zion,
    which has devoured its foundations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The kings of the earth didn’t believe,
    neither did all the inhabitants of the world,
    that the adversary and the enemy would enter into the gates of Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is because of the sins of her prophets
    and the iniquities of her priests,
    that have shed the blood of the just in the middle of her.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They wander as blind men in the streets.
    They are polluted with blood,
    So that men can’t touch their garments.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Go away!” they cried to them.
    “Unclean! Go away! Go away! Don’t touch!
When they fled away and wandered, men said among the nations,
    “They can’t live here any more.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yahweh’s anger has scattered them.
    He will not pay attention to them any more.
They didn’t respect the persons of the priests.
    They didn’t favor the elders.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Our eyes still fail,
    looking in vain for our help.
    In our watching we have watched for a nation that could not save.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They hunt our steps,
    so that we can’t go in our streets.
Our end is near.
    Our days are fulfilled,
    for our end has come.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Our pursuers were swifter than the eagles of the sky.
    They chased us on the mountains.
    They set an ambush for us in the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The breath of our nostrils,
    the anointed of Yahweh,
    was taken in their pits;
of whom we said,
    under his shadow we will live among the nations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Rejoice and be glad, daughter of Edom,
    who dwells in the land of Uz.
The cup will pass through to you also.
    You will be drunken,
    and will make yourself naked.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The punishment of your iniquity is accomplished, daughter of Zion.
    He will no more carry you away into captivity.
He will visit your iniquity, daughter of Edom.
    He will uncover your sins.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Remember, Yahweh, what has come on us.
    Look, and see our reproach.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Our inheritance has been turned over to strangers,
    our houses to aliens.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We are orphans and fatherless.
    Our mothers are as widows.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We must pay for water to drink.
    Our wood is sold to us.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Our pursuers are on our necks.
    We are weary, and have no rest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We have given our hands to the Egyptians,
    and to the Assyrians, to be satisfied with bread.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Our fathers sinned, and are no more.
    We have borne their iniquities.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Servants rule over us.
    There is no one to deliver us out of their hand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We get our bread at the peril of our lives,
    because of the sword in the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Our skin is black like an oven,
    because of the burning heat of famine.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They ravished the women in Zion,
    the virgins in the cities of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Princes were hanged up by their hands.
    The faces of elders were not honored.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The young men carry millstones.
    The children stumbled under loads of wood.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The elders have ceased from the gate,
    and the young men from their music.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The joy of our heart has ceased.
    Our dance is turned into mourning.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The crown has fallen from our head.
    Woe to us, for we have sinned!
speaker: Narrator

text:
For this our heart is faint.
    For these things our eyes are dim:
speaker: Narrator

text:
for the mountain of Zion, which is desolate.
    The foxes walk on it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You, Yahweh, remain forever.
    Your throne is from generation to generation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why do you forget us forever,
    and forsake us for so long a time?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Turn us to yourself, Yahweh, and we will be turned.
    Renew our days as of old.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But you have utterly rejected us.
    You are very angry against us.
speaker: Narrator
